Graphical abstract Transition metal based materials containing Fe have drawn great attention as oxygen evolution reaction (OER) catalysts. The nature of the electrocatalytic active species remains under debate due to the ambiguous physicochemical properties of the catalyst materials, such as the oxidation states and crystal structures. Here, in order to address this issue, transition metal Prussian blue analogues (TM-PBA, Na(TM)(Fe)(CN)6, TM = V, Fe, Co, and Ni) with an isomorphous structure are investigated for OER catalysis. Our combined experimental measurements and density functional theory (DFT) calculations reveal that TM-PBAs exhibit volcano-like OER activity with Ni-PBA located near the top of the volcano. Such a volcano-like activity profile can be attributed to the distinctive binding energy difference between *O and *OH on different TM-PBAs surfaces. This work demonstrates that TM-PBAs can be used as platform materials for understanding structure-property-activity relationships in OER catalysts. Keywords Oxygen evolution reaction Prussian blue analogues Platform materials Binding energy difference Density functional theory 1 Introduction The electrochemical oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is a key component to various applications such as water electrolysis, electrochemical and photoelectrochemical reduction of CO2, and metal-air batteries [1–10]. However, a high energy barrier is required to make OER happen, which is associated with the four-electron transfer, multiple reaction intermediates (*OH, *O, and *OOH) and O–O bond formation in OER [11–13]. Therefore, to address its slow kinetics and large overpotentials, various electrocatalysts have been proposed, such as iridium oxide (IrO2) and ruthenium oxide (RuO2) [14,15]. Despite their outstanding performance at acidic and alkaline conditions, those electrocatalysts are based on precious metals, thus driving the interest of the OER research into non-precious metal-based catalysts. Along with this direction, mixed transition metal (TM)-based electrocatalysts containing Fe have received great attention because they have shown successful OER performance in terms of overpotentials, onset potentials, and current densities [16–23]. However, the reaction mechanism for OER is still under debate. Such an issue is believed to originate from the unclear electrocatalyst structure. For example, Fe-doped α-/γ-NiOOH is one of the benchmark OER electrocatalysts [19–26]. Even though the reaction mechanisms [19–23] have been predicted by density functional theory (DFT) calculations, conclusion is under debate because the DFT calculations have been performed on a somewhat arbitrary γ-(Ni,Fe)OOH structure that does not reflect the reality well in terms of the oxidation state of TM, interlayer spacing of TM slabs, and the amount of intercalants (e.g., H2O and anions) [27,28]. Therefore, it is desirable to obtain fundamental understanding of the effect of different TM within the same structural motif on the OER performance, which in turn should provide guidance on the design and optimization of new OER catalysts. In order to further understand the role of TM on OER, Prussian blue analogues (PBAs) are adopted in this study as a material platform for OER electrocatalysts with identical structures. Prussian blue (AFe2(CN)6, where A is alkali metal ion such as Na and K) has a cubic framework (space group: Fm-3m) with divalent Fe and trivalent Fe being located on corners of a cube in an alternate manner and with each cube consisting of corner-shared octahedra linked with cyano groups ((C≡N)−) as an organic linker (Fig. 1 A) [29–31]. The C atom in this linker exclusively bonds with the low-spin Fe3+ ions (d 5 = t 2g 5 e g 0) while the N atom bonds with the high-spin Fe2+ ions (d 6 = t 2g 4 e g 2). Other TM2+ ions can be substituted for the Fe2+ to form a series of PBAs (A(TM)Fe(CN)6) without sacrificing the original crystallographic properties such as the local coordination environment around TM and Fe ions. Therefore, in this study, PBAs with different TMs (TM = V, Fe, Co, and Ni), referred to as TM-PBAs, can enable one to correlate the effect of varying the choice of TM on the OER performance. Based on the volcano-like OER activity profile achieved with different TM-PBAs, the current investigation offers useful insight into designing TM-based OER electrocatalysts toward optimizing the interactions between OER intermediates. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Preparation of TM-PBAs Unless otherwise noticed, all of the chemicals were purchased from Sigma Aldrich and used without any purification. PBAs were synthesized at room temperature [31]. First, 3 mmol of sodium ferrocyanide decahydrate (Na4Fe(CN)6·10H2O) was dissolved into 100 mL of deionized water (Solution A), followed by the addition of sodium chloride (7 g, NaCl). After 30 min of magnetic stirring, 50 mL deionized water containing different transition metal (TM) salts (1.5 mmol, TM = V, Fe, Co, and Ni) was dropwise added into Solution A. For the precursors containing TM, vanadium(II) chloride (VCl2), iron(II) chloride tetrahydrate (FeCl2·4H2O), cobalt(II) chloride hexahydrate (CoCl2·6H2O), and nickel(II) chloride hexahydrate (NiCl2·6H2O) were utilized. After vigorous stirring for 3 h, the mixed solution was ultrasonicated for 30 min, followed by aging for 12 h. The precipitated PBAs were collected after centrifugation and washed thoroughly using deionized water and ethanol. The obtained powders were vacuum-dried for 12 h. Then, the final PBAs with different TMs (TM-PBAs) were obtained. The field emission-scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM, Sirion, FEI) was used to characterize the morphologies of the TM-PBAs. High resolution scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM, Talos F200X, FEI) was used to chracterize the elemental distributions. An IrO2/C sample was synthesized to serve as a reference OER catalyst. 500 mg of ammonium hexachloroiridate ((NH4)2IrCl6) was dispersed into 50 mL of deionized water containing hexadecyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB, 10 mg), followed by a vigorous stirring until the deionized water evaporated. Then, the obained powder was calcined at 500 °C to obtain IrO2, and was finely mixed with carbon black (C, Vulkan XC-72, Carbot) to achieve the 20 wt% loading of IrO2. 2.2 Preparation of working electrodes For the preparation of working electrodes, the series of TM-PBA was first finely mixed with carbon black (C, Vulcan XC-72, Carbot) in a mass ratio of 1:1 in order to compensate for their low electrical conductivity. Then, the TM-PBA/C was dispersed in the mixture of deionized water and isopropanol solution (v:v = 1:1) containing 0.5 wt% Nafion solution with a concentration of 7 mg mL−1. After ultrasonication for 10 min, the homogeneous catalyst ink was dropped and dried on the carbon current collector electrode (TGP-H-060, 10% waterproofed, Toray). The areal mass loading was fixed at 700 μg cm−2 for all TM-PBA catalysts. 2.3 Electrochemical measurement The electrochemical performance was measured by using a VMP-3 potentiostat/galvanostat (Biologic) with a three-electrode configuration. A reversible hydrogen electrode (HydroFlex, ET-070, EDAQ) and graphite paper were used as reference and counter electrodes, respectively. 1 M sodium hydroxide (NaOH) solution purged with Ar was utilized as an electrolyte. During electrolysis, Ar stream was kept continuously into the electrolyte to eliminate the dissolved oxygen molecules, which otherwise might cause the artificial oxidation of materials.[32] In order to obtain the solution resistance in the Nyquist plot, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) analysis was conducted in the frequency range of 5 MHz to 0.5 Hz with an AC signal of 10 mV (Fig. S1). The working electrode potential (VRHE) was controlled by iR-compensation (85%). The overpotential was defined as the potential difference between the working electrode and the theoretical oxygen evolution reaction potentials (i.e., 1.23 VRHE). In order to obtain stable electrochemical data, 5 cyclic voltammetry (CV) scans were performed with a scan rate of 50 mV s−1. After that, the working electrodes were scanned by using the linear scanning voltammetry (LSV) technique with a scan rate of 5 mV s−1. The stability tests were conducted using the controlled-current electrolysis (chronopotentiometry) method at the current density of 1 mA cm−2. Electrochemical surface area (ECSA) [33] was obtained from the electrical double layer capacitance (EDLC) measurement assuming a unit areal capacitance of 60 μF cm−2. The double layer capacitance was calculated by plotting the current densities at 0.9 VRHE as a function of different scan rates (100, 50, and 20 mV s−1). 2.4 Synchrotron X-ray diffraction analysis Synchrotron X-ray diffraction (XRD) data were recorded on the 17-BM-B beamline (λ = 0.24156 Å) at Advanced Photon Sources (APS) with a sample-to-detector distance of 800 mm. A Perkin-Elmer amorphous silicon detector was used. The obtained 2D ring patterns were integrated and converted to 1D diffraction patterns using the GSAS-II software [34]. The obtained XRD patterns were analyzed with Le Bail profile fitting [35]. All crystal structures were visualized using the VESTA (Visualization for Electronic and Structure Analysis) software [36]. The Le Bail fit results are tabulated in Table S1. In order to monitor the structural changes after OER, ex-situ XRD analysis was conducted. For this analysis, the working electrodes were scanned up to target potentials (i.e., 1.7 and 1.0 VRHE) and the potentials were held for 30 min to get the electrodes in equilibrium states. Next, the working electrodes were scraped off from the current collectors using a blade, followed by loading them into the capillary tubes (Polyimide, Cole-Parmer, Model: 95820-90) and plugging the ends with clay to avoid air exposure. Then, the tubes were fully-dried using a vacuum dryer for XRD characterization. To verify the structural evolution of Ni-PBA during OER over a longer period of time, additional ex-situ XRD analysis was conducted. The working electrodes were held at 1.6 VRHE for different electrolysis periods. Then, the working electrodes were scraped off and sandwiched between two pieces of Kapton tape, followed by XRD measurements. The XRD pattern of the working electrode was obtained by subtracting that of the blank Kapton tape. 2.5 X-ray absorption fine structure analysis X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) analysis was conducted to obtain chemical information of TMs during OER. In-situ and ex-situ XAFS analyses were performed on the 8-ID (ISS) and 7-BM (QAS) beamlines at National Synchrotron Light Source II (NSLS-II), respectively. The obtained spectra were processed using the IFFEFFIT package [37,38]. For in-situ XAFS analysis, the areal mass loading of the working electrode was ~7 mg cm−2 to achieve sufficient XAFS signal. A laboratory-made H-shaped acryl cell was used for in-situ electrochemical operations [39]. During the measurements, Ar gas was continuously bubbled into the electrolyte. The potential was swept at a scan rate of 0.05 mV sec −1 from 1 to 1.6 VRHE. The other conditions were the same as in the electrochemical measurements. For ex-situ XAFS analysis, the aforementioned sample-containing tubes in ex-situ XRD analyses were used. V K-edge measurement was carried out under ex-situ conditions because of its low energy and co-existence of Fe. As V-PBA contains V and Fe, the transmission signal (E0 = 5465 eV) cannot pass through the sample due to the presence of Fe (E0 = 7112 eV). On the other hand, in the in-situ measurement the fluorescent signal can hardly escape from the electrolyte due to its low energy (K-L3 transition = 4952 eV). For the extended XAFS (EXAFS) analysis for the series of TM-PBAs upon the completion of OER test at 1.7 VRHE, the original EXAFS pattern (χ(k)) was weighted with k 3 in order to intensify the high-k oscillation regime and was Fourier transformed using a Hanning window. The amplitude reduction factor (S0 2) was attained from the corresponding metal foils. All of the EXAFS fittings were done in the R-space. All fitting parameters and results are tabulated in Tables S2–S9. 2.6 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy analysis X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, PHI-5600, PHI, chamber pressure = 4x10−9 Torr) was used to characterize the concentration and chemical state of Ni in the Ni-PBA electrodes before and after electrolysis. For this analysis, fresh and spent electrodes were utilized. The spent electrode was prepared by the OER test for 1 h and the subsequent chronoamperometry at the potential of 0.8 VRHE for 10 min. 2.7 Density functional theory calculations Spin polarized DFT calculations [40,41] were performed with the PAW-PW91 potential [42,43] including an on-site Coulombic interaction term (DFT + U) [44] using the Vienna Ab-Initio Simulation Package (VASP) code [45,46]. Electronic exchange and correlation effects were described within the generalized gradient approximation (GGA). Out of all the available versions of PAW potentials, the standard versions with no extensions were used in our calculations. A plane wave cut-off energy of 400 eV was used for all total energy calculations. The U values used in our DFT calculations are similar to those used in previous DFT + U studies [47–51]. For example, U values of 3.0 eV and 7.0 eV were used for Fe2+ and Fe3+ sites in Fe-PBA, respectively, consistent with the previous DFT + U study of the electronic structure of Fe-PBA [47]. Similar to several previous studies [48–51], a U value of 3 eV was used for Co, V and Cu, and a U value of 4 eV was used for Ni ions. Consistent with the synchrotron X-ray analysis and STEM observations, the TM-PBAs in our DFT calculations were modelled without sodium ions using face centered cubic structures (Space group: Fm-3m). The unit cells used in the DFT calculations contained 8 TM atoms, 24 N atoms and 24C atoms. A 10 × 10 × 10 Monkhorst-Pack grid [52] was used for bulk calculations. The DFT calculated lattice parameters along with the U values used are summarized in Table S10. The XRD measurements suggested that the (100) facet was the most dominant facet in our synthesized TM-PBA. Therefore, the TM-PBA(100) surface was chosen as a representative surface of TM-PBA in this study. The TM-PBA(100) surface was modeled as a 2 layers 2 × 2 surface. A 3 × 3 × 1 Monkhorst-Pack grid [52] was used for all surface calculations. A vacuum layer of ~15 Å thick was added in the slab cell along the direction perpendicular to the surface to minimize the artificial interactions between the surface and its periodic images. Atoms in the bottom two layers were fixed while all other atoms were allowed to relax during geometry optimization until the Hellman-Feynman force on each ion was smaller than 0.02 eV/Å. Following a similar approach described elsewhere [23], the binding energies of previously identified key reaction intermediates, *O and *OH, were calculated [12] using the following Eqs. (1) and (2): (1) Δ E ( ∗ O ) = E ( O + slab ) - E ( slab ) - [ E ( H 2 O - E ( H 2 ) ] (2) Δ E ( ∗ O H ) = E ( OH + slab ) - E ( slab ) - [ E ( H 2 O - 1 / 2 E ( H 2 ) ] where, E(O + slab), E(OH + slab), E(slab), E(H2O) and E(H2) are total energies of O adsorbed slab, OH adsorbed slab, clean slab, H2O in the gas phase and H2 in the gas phase, respectively. 3 Results and discussion Different TM-PBAs catalysts were successfully synthesized by co-precipitation of TM-containing chloride and sodium ferrocyanide in an aqueous solution [31]. Field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM) images shown in Fig. S2 indicate that the aqueous co-precipitation produced aggregated micron size particles. Such an agglomeration is attributed to the absence of a chelating agent that can control a nucleation growth rate during the synthesis step [53,54]. The structure of TM-PBAs was characterized using synchrotron X-ray diffraction (XRD) with a wavelength of 0.24156 Å (Fig. 1 B), revealing that these materials hold a face-centered cubic (fcc) phase (Fm-3m) [29–31]. The lattice constants obtained from the Le Bail fitting (Fig. S3) are listed along with each XRD profile [35]. The degree of fitting is evaluated based on the goodness of fit (GoF) and the reliable factors [55]. The fitting factors are tabulated in Table S1. The TM-PBAs in this study are characterized by similar lattice constants because of the similar ionic radii of the TMs [56]. Compared with the other PBAs, the XRD peaks of V-PBA appear broader, which is associated with the relatively unstable V2+ ions that can lead to the lattice disordering and amorphization [57]. All of the catalysts showed the reversible oxidation and reduction peaks in cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves at different scan rates (Fig. 2 ), suggesting that TMs were oxidized and reduced in a reversible manner within the PBA framework. In the LSV profile of TM-PBAs at a scan rate of 1 mV s−1 (Fig. S4), the anodic peaks were also observed in the range of 1.0–1.5 VRHE, implying that the oxidation of TM happened concurrently with the removal of sodium ion from the host framework before OER. This is consistent with the progressive oxidation state change of TMs observed in in-situ X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) analysis, which will be discussed later. The electrocatalytic OER activity of TM-PBAs was evaluated using the linear scanning voltammetry (LSV) method at a scan rate of 5 mV s−1 (Fig. 3 A). In the LSV profiles of Co-PBA and Ni-PBA (Inset in Fig. 3 A), the anodic peaks are also observed in the range of 1.0 to 1.4 VRHE. Such anodic peaks in V-PBA and Fe-PBA seem to be overlapping with their OER current profiles in Fig. 3 A because those peaks are clearly observed near 1.3 VRHE in the CV curves in the potential range where their OER current contributes negligibly (Fig. 2). On the other hand, ex-situ XRD analyses show that TM-PBAs maintain the original crystal structure after OER (Fig. S5), which is also consistent with the previous reports [58,59] that PBAs retain the crystal structure after the given electrocatalytic reactions. Upon the completion of OER, the XRD profiles of TM-PBAs show a shift of diffraction peaks toward higher 2θ values, suggesting that the enhanced Coulombic attraction between the higher-valent TM and anionic cyano group leads to a lattice shrinkage. However, the profiles recover back to the original ones after electrochemical treatment at 1 VRHE in the XRD measurements, demonstrating the robust structure of TM-PBAs. Moreover, elemental mapping analysis of Ni-PBA using scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) verify that the elemental distributions remain unchanged over the Ni-PBA particle before and after OER, indicating again the stable PBA frameworks (Fig. S6). Additional ex-situ XRD and STEM measurements confirm that Ni-PBA maintain the original structure even after OER for 4 h (2 supporting again the role of PBAs as a platform material for OER electrocatalysts. It is noteworthy that the OER performance shows a dependence on the choice of TMs. As compared in Fig. 3 B, when TM changes from V (Z = 23) to Ni (Z = 28), the overpotentials, required for the same current densities such as 5 (black) and 10 (red) mA cm−2, continue to decrease. Likewise, the current densities at the same overpotential of 1.6 (black) and 1.7 (red) VRHE follow the trend observed in the overpotentials (Fig. 3 C). Ni-PBA shows the highest current densities of 59 mA cm−2, followed by Co-PBA (54 mA cm−2), Fe-PBA (5.7 mA cm−2), and V-PBA (3.2 mA cm−2). The calculated Tafel slopes also depict a similar trend (Fig. 3 D). Ni-PBA and Co-PBA exhibit the superior OER kinetics (37.7 and 31.7 mV dec−1, respectively), clearly better than those of Fe-PBA (60.7 mV dec−1) and V-PBA (44.5 mV dec−1). The different Tafel slope values of TM-PBAs indicate that different TM-PBA may have a different rate determining step [60]. The catalytic stability tests were also performed using the chronopotentiometry method at the current density of 1 mA cm−2 for 15 h (Fig. 3 E). Because of the aggregated particle morphology of TM-PBAs (Fig. S2) and the resulting current density lower than the previous reports on nanostructured PBAs [58,59], a value of 1 mA cm−2 was selected for the chropotentiometry measurement. All of the samples show decent stability performance, which is also consistent with ex-situ XRD analysis (Fig. S5), showing that all the catalysts maintain the original XRD profiles after OER. Furthermore, the average overpotentials of the samples during OER for 15 h are compared in Fig. 3 F. The average OER potential follows the same trend as shown above, with Ni-PBA showing the markedly lowest overpotential of 0.248 V among different TM-PBAs. Stability test under the chronoamperometry mode over a longer period also show the same tendency (Fig. S8). The reason for the gradual enhancement in the electrochemical performance of Fe-PBA during the stability test might originate from the activation of the electrode during the test. A IrO2/C catalyst was also synthesized and tested in the same way with a series of TM-PBAs (Fig. S9) for a comparison. The OER performance and electrochemical surface area (ECSA) values[33] of TM-PBAs in this study are summarized in Table S11 and Table 1 , respectively. In order to determine the oxidation state variation of TMs during OER, XAFS analysis [37–39] was conducted at TM (TM = V, Fe, Co, and Ni) K-edge (Figs. 4 and 5 ). In-situ XAFS analyses at Fe, Co, and Ni K-edges were conducted with the LSV mode from 1.0 to 1.6 VRHE, while V K-edge measurement was performed under ex-situ conditions for reasons described in the Experimental Section. The X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) profiles at the TM K-edges show a gradual shift toward higher energy during the anodic scan. By considering the redox peaks observed in Fig. 2 and the energy shifts in the XANES profiles, the oxidation state change of TM is attributed to the removal of sodium ion and the subsequent OER. Ex-situ XAFS analyses confirmed the reversible change in the oxidation state of TMs in the XANES profiles (Figs. S10 and S11) and in the local structure around TMs in the EXAFS profiles (Figs. S12 and S13). The EXAFS fitting upon the completion of OER test at 1.7 VRHE further confirmed that the TM-PBAs maintained the original PBA framework (Figs. S14 and S15), consistent with XRD results (Fig. S5) that the TM-PBA framework remains stable during OER. This is also consistent with the negligible change in the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements of the Ni 2p and O 1s regions of Ni-PBA before and after OER (Fig. S16). The minor difference between in-situ and ex-situ XAFS analyses might be attributed to the water uptake capability of TM-PBAs and the consequent charge transfer between the host framework and guest water molecules [61]. This is also supported by a picture showing the color-change of Ni-PBA before and after air-exposure for 30 min (Fig. S17). The OER takes place through the oxygen-containing intermediates, *OH, *O, and *OOH [11–13,22,23,62–64]. Among the three intermediates, the scaling relation [12] between the binding energies of *OH and *OOH is now well-established with their energy difference being nearly constant, enabling one to focus on the binding energies of *OH and *O (i.e., ΔE(*OH) and ΔE(*O)) for correlating the OER activity of a catalyst. This approach [12], developed by Nørskov and Rossmeisl et al., has identified the binding energy difference (ΔE(*OH)– ΔE(*O)) as an effective descriptor of OER activity. Inspired by such an approach, DFT calculations [40–46,52] were performed to gain insight into the experimentally observed OER activity trend among the various TM-PBA catalysts (Table S11). The ΔE(*OH) and ΔE(*O) calculated using the optimized *OH and *O geometries (Fig. 6 A and 6B) on TM-PBA surfaces, respectively, were used to compute the ΔE(*OH)– ΔE(*O) values. Then, the calculated ΔE(*OH)– ΔE(*O) is plotted against the experimental OER activity [12,23] (OER overpotential and current density), which shows a volcano-like correlation as displayed in Fig. 6 C and 6D. The OER activity of Ni-PBA is located near the top of the volcano with ΔE(*OH)– ΔE(*O) value of −1.92 eV, which is close to the optimal ΔE(*OH)– ΔE(*O) value in the previous report [23]. The ΔE(*OH)– ΔE(*O) values for V-PBA and Fe-PBA are −0.82 eV and −3.10 eV and are located at right and left of the volcano, respectively. The DFT calculated ΔE(*OH)– ΔE(*O) for Co-PBA is −1.79 eV and its OER activity is predicted to be slightly lower than Ni-PBA. Thus, Ni-PBA provides the optimal ΔE(*OH)– ΔE(*O) value, leading to the enhanced OER activity compared to the other TM-PBAs in the current study. 4 Conclusion In conclusion, we investigated TM-PBAs as a platform material for OER electrocatalysts owing to their well-defined crystal structure even after replacing different TM ions. The isomorphous character of TM-PBAs allowed us to focus on the effect of TM replacement on OER electrocatalysis. Electrochemical measurements and X-ray characterization provided a fundamental understanding of how TM contributes to the OER activity. The insights into trends in OER activity of TM-PBAs were obtained by DFT calculations, which showed a volcano-like correlation between ΔE(*OH)– ΔE(*O) and OER activities. The findings in the current study suggest that TM-PBAs can be used as platform materials for understanding and developing electrocatalysts for the OER and potentially other electrochemical reactions. coredata.dc:description: Transition metal based materials containing Fe have drawn great attention as oxygen evolution reaction (OER) catalysts. The nature of the electrocatalytic active species remains under debate due to the ambiguous physicochemical properties of the catalyst materials, such as the oxidation states and crystal structures. Here, in order to address this issue, transition metal Prussian blue analogues (TM-PBA, Na(TM)(Fe)(CN)6, TM = V, Fe, Co, and Ni) with an isomorphous structure are investigated for OER catalysis. Our combined experimental measurements and density functional theory (DFT) calculations reveal that TM-PBAs exhibit volcano-like OER activity with Ni-PBA located near the top of the volcano. Such a volcano-like activity profile can be attributed to the distinctive binding energy difference between *O and *OH on different TM-PBAs surfaces. This work demonstrates that TM-PBAs can be used as platform materials for understanding structure-property-activity relationships in OER catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Prussian blue analogues as platform materials for understanding and developing oxygen evolution reaction electrocatalysts
